SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: I was three times Tunisia in last two years after the revolution. I was in almost every part of the country even the red areas without any safety issues
I always communicated I'd go back anytime, because shit can happen anytime, anywhere. I communicated it when i came home 2 days before Bardo museum attack when 21 people died.

My last short 3 days trip was in previous week. I was in Tunis and Sousse. I feel fine myself , i contacted a lot with locals, walked a lot, used public transportation as usual, i came home in Thursday. In Friday at least 38 people is killed. Both Bardo and Sousse are in "safe" green areas. So this is the point when i feel it's too much. Tunisia deceived me. I was wrong when i communicated it's safe as a whole and shit can happen anywhere. I think this situation is more than an ugly accident. Tunisia can't control extremism. These two place was amongst the most safe areas of the country. I feel sorry for this fantastic country but i feel Tunisia is lost now. Tourism is very important to them, but tourists will avoid this country, poverty will be growing, extremism will be growing, problems will be growing. this is a vicious circle. Thoughts?

You know what... I don't understand why Euros go to MENA in general. I mean, yeah, Egypt is great n all, but you have places like Greece, spain etc... all in Europe, more organized, more hygenic, similar mentality etc... Then you have south America, well and North America (very beautiful), South and East Asia... all nice places.
The MENA region will be a shithole, like westerners like to call, for a while if we are optimistic. So it's better to cross these places as an option for Europeans. JMO
